column1: Miami and its suburbs are located on a broad plain between the Everglades to the west and Biscayne Bay to the east
column2: which extends from Lake Okeechobee southward to Florida Bay. The elevation of the area averages at around 6 ft (1.8 m) above sea level in most neighborhoods
column3: especially near the coast. The highest points are found along the Miami Rock Ridge
column4: which lies under most of the eastern Miami metro. The main portion of the city is on the shores of Biscayne Bay
column5: which contains several hundred natural and artificial barrier islands
column6: the largest of which contains Miami Beach and South Beach. The Gulf Stream
column7: a warm ocean current
column8: runs northward just 15 miles (24 km) off the coast
column9: allowing the city's climate to stay warm and mild all year.

column1: The surface bedrock under the Miami area is called Miami oolite or Miami limestone. This bedrock is covered by a thin layer of soil
column2: and is no more than 50 feet (15 m) thick. Miami limestone formed as the result of the drastic changes in sea level associated with recent glacial periods
column3: or ice ages. Beginning some 130
column4: 000 years ago
column5: the Sangamonian Stage raised sea levels to approximately 25 feet (8 m) above the current level. All of southern Florida was covered by a shallow sea. Several parallel lines of reef formed along the edge of the submerged Florida plateau
column6: stretching from the present Miami area to what is now the Dry Tortugas. The area behind this reef line was in effect a large lagoon
column7: and the Miami limestone formed throughout the area from the deposition of oolites and the shells of bryozoans. Starting about 100
column8: 000 years ago
column9: the Wisconsin glaciation began lowering sea levels
column10: exposing the floor of the lagoon. By 15
column11: 000 years ago
column12: the sea level had dropped 300 to 350 feet (90 to 110 m) below the current level. The sea level rose quickly after that
column13: stabilizing at the current level about 4
column15: leaving the mainland of South Florida just above sea level.Beneath the plain lies the Biscayne Aquifer
column16: a natural underground source of fresh water that extends from southern Palm Beach County to Florida Bay. It comes closest to the surface around the cities of Miami Springs and Hialeah. Most of the Miami metropolitan area obtains its drinking water from the Biscayne Aquifer. As a result of the aquifer
column17: it is not possible to dig more than 15 to 20 ft (5 to 6 m) beneath the city without hitting water
column19: though some underground parking garages exist. For this reason
column20: the mass transit systems in and around Miami are elevated or at-grade.Most of the western fringes of the city border the Everglades
column21: a tropical marshland covering most of the southern portion of Florida. Alligators that live in the marshes have ventured into Miami communities and onto major highways.In terms of land area

column24: of which 35.99 sq mi (93.2 km2) is land and 20.08 sq mi (52.0 km2) is water. That means Miami comprises over 470
column25: 000 people in about 36 square miles (93 km2)
column26: making it one of the most densely populated cities in the United States

column1: Miami has a tropical monsoon climate (Köppen climate classification Am) with a marked drier season in the winter. Although it is relatively cooler than most other tropical places in the winter and does get occasional 40 degree Fahrenheit (4 °C) lows
column2: Miami nevertheless meets the minimum requirements to be in the tropical climate zone
column3: making it one of the northernmost major cities on Earth within this classification.

column2: coastal location
column3: position just above the Tropic of Cancer
column4: and proximity to the Gulf Stream shape its climate. Average winter high temperatures
column6: range from 76.4–80.3 °F (24.7–26.8 °C). January is the coolest month with an average daily temperature of 68.2 °F (20.1 °C). Low temperatures fall below 50 °F (10 °C) about 10–15 nights during the winter season
column7: after the passage of cold fronts that produce much of the winter rainfall.

column1: The wet season begins sometime in June

column7: 1942. While Miami has never recorded snowfall at any official weather station since records have been kept
column8: snow flurries fell in some parts of the city on January 19
column9: 1977.Hurricane season officially runs from June 1 through November 30

column12: one struck in 1925 and another in 1997. Around 40% of homes in Miami are built upon floodplains and are considered as flood-risk zones.Miami falls under the Department of Agriculture's 10b/11a plant hardiness zone.

column11: and Northeast American dialects and Florida Cracker dialect
column12: "Miami accent" is rhotic; it also incorporates a rhythm and pronunciation heavily influenced by Spanish (wherein rhythm is syllable-timed).This is a native dialect of English
column13: not learner English or interlanguage; it is possible to differentiate this variety from an interlanguage spoken by second-language speakers in that the "Miami accent" does not generally display the following features: there is no addition of /ɛ/ before initial consonant clusters with /s/
column14: speakers do not confuse of /dʒ/ with /j/
column17: and /r/ and /rr/ are pronounced as alveolar approximant [ɹ] instead of alveolar tap [ɾ] or alveolar trill [r] in Spanish.

column1: The government of the City of Miami uses the mayor-commissioner type of system. The city commission consists of five commissioners that are elected from single member districts. The city commission constitutes the governing body with powers to pass ordinances
column2: adopt regulations
column3: and exercise all powers conferred upon the city in the city charter. The mayor is elected at large and appoints a city manager. The City of Miami is governed by Mayor Francis X. Suarez and 5 city commissioners that oversee the five districts in the city. The commission's regular meetings are held at Miami City Hall
column4: which is located at 3500 Pan American Drive on Dinner Key in the neighborhood of Coconut Grove.

column1: Miami's road system is based along the numerical Miami grid where Flagler Street forms the east–west baseline and Miami Avenue forms the north–south meridian. The corner of Flagler Street and Miami Avenue is in the middle of Downtown in front of the Downtown Macy's (formerly the Burdine's headquarters). The Miami grid is primarily numerical so that
column2: for example
column3: all street addresses north of Flagler Street and west of Miami Avenue have "NW" in their address. Because its point of origin is in Downtown
column4: which is close to the coast
column5: the "NW" and "SW" quadrants are much larger than the "SE" and "NE" quadrants. Many roads
column7: are also named (e.g.
column8: Tamiami Trail/SW 8th St)
column10: with exceptions
column11: the number is in more common usage among locals.

column4: Avenues or Places (often remembered by their acronym)
column7: Drives or occasionally Ways.  Major roads in each direction are located at one mile intervals. There are 16 blocks to each mile on north–south avenues
column8: and 10 blocks to each mile on east–west streets.  Major north–south avenues generally end in "7" – e.g.
column10: 27th
column11: 37th/Douglas Aves.
column12: 57th/Red Rd.
column16: all the way west beyond 177th/Krome Avenue.  (One prominent exception is 42nd Avenue
column18: located at the half-mile point instead.)  Major east–west streets to the south of downtown are multiples of 16
column19: though the beginning point of this system is at SW 8th St
column20: one half mile south of Flagler ("zeroth") Street.  Thus
column38: well into the 300s.  Within the grid
column39: odd-numbered addresses are generally on the north or east side
column40: and even-numbered addresses are on the south or west side.

Miami has six major causeways that span over Biscayne Bay connecting the western mainland
column2: with the eastern barrier islands along the Atlantic Ocean. The Rickenbacker Causeway is the southernmost causeway and connects Brickell to Virginia Key and Key Biscayne. The Venetian Causeway and MacArthur Causeway connect Downtown with South Beach. The Julia Tuttle Causeway connects Midtown and Miami Beach. The 79th Street Causeway connects the Upper East Side with North Beach. The northernmost causeway
column3: the Broad Causeway
column4: is the smallest of Miami's six causeways and connects North Miami with Bal Harbour.

column1: Public transportation in Miami is operated by Miami-Dade Transit and SFRTA

column4: an elevated people mover (Metromover)
column5: and buses (Metrobus). Miami has Florida's highest transit ridership as about 17% of Miamians use transit on a daily basis. The average Miami public transit commute on weekdays is 90 minutes
column6: while 39% of public transit riders commute for more than 2 hours a day. The average wait time at a public transit stop or station is 18 minutes
column7: while 37% of riders wait for more than 20 minutes on average every day. The average single trip distance with public transit is 7.46 mi (12 km)
column8: while 38% travel more than 8.08 mi (13 km) in each direction.Miami's heavy-rail rapid transit system

column1: Miami International Airport serves as the primary international airport of the Greater Miami Area. One of the busiest international airports in the world
column2: Miami International Airport caters to over 45 million passengers a year. The airport is a major hub and the largest international gateway for American Airlines. Miami International is the second busiest airport by passenger traffic in Florida
column3: the United States' third-largest international port of entry for foreign air passengers behind New York's John F. Kennedy International Airport and Los Angeles International Airport. The airport's extensive international route network includes non-stop flights to over seventy international cities in North and South America
column4: Europe
